Additionally, the romance subplot falls flat, lacking the depth and engagement needed to make it compelling.

The writing is overly simplistic, with characters often delivering lengthy monologues about their backstories and motivations at pivotal moments. The novel tends to spoon-feed basic themes, suggesting a lack of trust in the reader's ability to interpret the story.

The novel presents a captivating alternative post-colonial Latin America in the 16th century, enriched by the incorporation of Aztec and Mexican culture. The contrast between Leonora's confined existence in the palace and her sense of freedom in the Mexican jungles adds depth to the narrative.

The novel struggles to satisfy both historical fiction fans and fantasy enthusiasts, as it fails to fully embrace either genre. The reliance on Deus ex machina elements and overpowered characters diminishes the stakes and tension.
